protocol_name: Cat Scratch on Human - Cat Scratch Disease Risk

infection_risk.why_dangerous: Bartonella henselae causes Cat Scratch Disease (CSD), transmitted through scratches or bites, especially from kittens. Symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fever, and fatigue.

immediate_actions.action: Wash scratch thoroughly with soap and water
Cover with clean bandage if needed

seek_medical_attention.urgency: Low initially, HIGH if symptoms develop
seek_medical_attention.timeframe: If symptoms appear (7-14 days post-scratch), seek care within 24-48 hours
mandatory_if: Swollen lymph nodes near scratch site

antibiotics.prophylactic: Not typically given unless high risk

symptoms_to_watch: Swollen, tender lymph nodes (armpits, neck, groin)
Small red bump/blister at scratch site
monitoring.note: Most cases resolve without treatment in 2-4 months

kittens.reason: Kittens more likely to carry Bartonella

full_protocol_text: Cat scratches carry 30-40% risk of Cat Scratch Disease (CSD) caused by Bartonella henselae bacteria, especially from kittens. Immediate action: Wash scratch with soap and water for 5 minutes, rinse, apply antibiotic ointment, cover if needed. Most scratches heal without issue. Monitor for 7-21 days for CSD symptoms: swollen lymph nodes near scratch site, small red bump at scratch, fever, fatigue. Symptoms typically appear 7-14 days post-scratch. If symptoms develop, seek medical care - azithromycin may be prescribed. Most cases resolve in 2-4 months without treatment. Immunocompromised individuals at higher risk for severe complications. Prevent scratches: avoid play that provokes cats, trim cat nails, teach children gentle handling.
